tossups.question: One character in this play lists “child, love, lawyer, judge, friend” - “every word has a new meaning” and bemoans a life of being “sick, high-tragic people.” That woman in this play later declares “I won’t be your confessor...I have a dead friend. Get out of here and be noble on the street.” One character in this play pretends to be sick after being forbidden to go to boat-races. That character in this play uses knowledge of a stolen bracelet to force a girl to be her “vassal” and to verify a story based on a hidden copy of (*) Mademoiselle de Maupin and a conversation overheard by Evelyn Munn and Peggy Rogers. That conversation in this play revealed a character’s jealousy of Joe Cardin, driving her to commit suicide after confessing “maybe I love you… [the] way they said.” For 10 points, name this play in which Mary Tilford accuses her teachers Martha Dobie and Karen Wright of having a lesbian affair, by Lillian Hellman.

Mutations in BMPR2 cause the familial form of one disease named for this structure; that disease named for this structure is sorted into five groups by a WHO classification. The wedge pressure can be measured by placing a Swan Ganz catheter into this structure. Endothelin receptor antagonists and prostacyclin (“praw-stuh-sy-klin”) agonists are used to relieve high pressure in this structure, which is usually 8-20 mm of mercury. The main trunk of this structure can be occluded by a (*) saddle embolus. This vessel is narrow in people with tetralogy of Fallot. The second component of the second heart sound is caused by the closure of the semilunar valve leading to this structure. In total dextro-transposition of the great vessels, this structure switches places with the aorta. For 10 points, name this vessel that carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.
tossups.answer: pulmonary artery [accept lung before “high pressure,” prompt after]

tossups.question: Robert Stalnaker proposed the concept of “selection functions” for performing formal analysis on statements of this type. In a 1947 paper about “The Problem of” these types of statements, Nelson Goodman argued that an “adequate” philosophy of science is impossible without the means to interpret them. A paper by Timothy Williamson partially titled for this type of thinking argues that questions of metaphysical (*) possibility and necessity are equivalent to questions about these types of statements. A work about these types of statements introduced operators like “box-arrow” by combining operators from classical and modal logic. That work about these types of statements analyzes them in terms of the semantics of possible worlds, uses them to formulate a theory of causation, and was written by David Lewis. For 10 points, identify these types of statements, which posit what might have happened if something else had been the case.

John MacDonald allowed Canadian voyageurs to guide a military expedition to this city in the first Canadian participation in an overseas conflict. The Palestinian Liberation Organization killed Cleo Noel, the U.S. ambassador in this city, after taking hostages at the Saudi embassy here in 1973. This city was founded in 1821 near the ruins of the ancient capital of Soba by Ibrahim Pasha. The Arab League convened and issued the “Three No’s” in a (*) resolution named for this city after their defeat in the Six-Day War. Garnet Wolseley led the Nile Expedition to relieve a siege of this city but arrived too late to prevent the death of General Charles Gordon. At the Battle of Omdurman, Herbert Kitchener retook this city from militant followers of Muhammad Ahmad, the self-proclaimed Mahdi. For 10 points, name this capital where Omar al-Bashir was recently toppled in Sudan.

A character portrayed by this actor initially refuses $50 he’s owed by his friend after he sees his friend pull the money from his shoe. That same character played by this actor appears on Judge Judy after being countersued by his neighbor for “plant abuse.” In another appearance, this man played a character who asks if he can “dial it right up to a 10” before proclaiming “We’re doomed! We need a revolution!” A character played by this actor says “I’m not Aaron Burr!” after (*) accidentally shooting Lin-Manuel Miranda in the mouth during a paintball duel. Bob Einstein and J.B. Smoove appear in a show created by and starring this actor, who also played Bernie Sanders in SNL during the 2016 presidential election. For 10 points, name this comedian known for co-creating Seinfeld and for starring as a fictionalized version of himself on the HBO show Curb Your Enthusiasm.

This culture’s great halls typically featured a central hearth, surrounded by four columns, which vented through a circular oculus in the ceiling. A sculpture by this culture depicts two headless animals with holes in their necks, implying that the heads would have been attached by dowels. Those carved animals flank a column and rest their front paws on a pedestal, forming a triangle that relieves the load on the underlying lintel. The only surviving monumental sculpture by this culture is the (*) Lion Gate at the entrance to this culture’s largest citadel. This culture developed the megaron and the tholos or beehive tomb, and built the palaces of Tiryns and Pylos. Most surviving tablets of the Linear B script were found at its palaces. For 10 points, name this civilization whose namesake archaeological site was the legendary home of Agamemnon.

On the eve of this decade, one leader gave a speech where he announced, “Yes, it is Europe, from the Atlantic to the Urals...that will decide the destiny of the world.” Gaston Palewski and other cabinet ministers were exposed to intense radiation after a nuclear testing mishap in the Béryl incident in this decade. France vetoed the UK’s entry into the European Common Market in this decade that all French forces (*) withdrew from the integrated NATO command structure. The OAS was founded in this decade to resist the conclusion of the Évian Accords, which granted independence to Algeria. The French president briefly fled to Baden near the end of this decade after crippling strikes and student protests in the month of May. For 10 points, Charles de Gaulle dominated which politically fraught countercultural decade in France?

A poet from this country wrote “Herrs and pukka-sahibs (“PUCK-uh SAH-heebs”), demoiselles and squaws; / all one family, so why make wars?” and “I’m for all humankind, not colour gibes; / I’m international, never mind tribes” in “All One Race.” This home of Kath Walker is also home to a poet who wrote “I had often cowled in the slumbrous heavy air, / Closed my inanimate lids to find it real” in “Durer: Innsbruck, 1495.” James McAuley and Harold Stewart, two other poets from this country, created that poet, (*) Ern Malley, to trick the modernist Angry Penguins literary magazine, inspiring My Life as a Fake. In another poem from this country, a “swagman” captures a “jumbuck” that comes to drink at a “billabong” before saying “You’ll come a-waltzing Matilda, with me.” For 10 points, name this country home to Banjo Paterson, known for his bush ballads about life in the Outback.

In one myth system, the first people on earth tried to dress up a man like one of these animals so it could make corn. In the absence of one of these animals, one god stomped his feet until a bag of stars reached his hands so he could create the Pleiades. Death is introduced into the world after one of these animals throws a rock into a lake to determine if a Nadleeh was dead; that animal, First Angry, is excluded from creating the Sun and Moon after he stole the children of a (*) Water Buffalo, which caused a flood in the Third World. One of these animals removes his heart and circulatory system to marry a Changing Bear Maiden, only for him to be killed by spiders. The Milky Way was created after one of these animals stole Black God’s stars. One of these animals kicked dirt which created the first humans. For 10 points, identify these animals who represent trickster gods in Native American myth.

The lineshape profile observed due to Doppler broadening in this effect can be expressed as a double integral over the electron momentum distribution function. In the first demonstration of this effect, K-alpha X-rays from molybdenum were beamed onto a graphite target and a Bragg spectrometer measured the output spectrum. This effect dominates light-matter interaction when the photon energy is intermediate between the high energies typical of (*) pair production and the low energies typical of the photoelectric effect. The change in wavelength in this effect depends only on the incident angle, and not the material that the photon hits. The low-energy limit of this effect is named for J.J. Thomson. For 10 points, name this effect in which some of a photon’s energy is transferred to an electron or other charged particle, named for an American physicist.
tossups.answer: Compton scattering [prompt on relativistic Thomson scattering before his name is read]

tossups.question: For petroleum derivatives, a version of this quantity is measured by cooling the mixture to 0 degrees celsius and pouring it into a D323 apparatus; that version of this quantity is named for Reid. The negative base 10 log of this quantity minus 1 at a reduced temperature of 0.7 gives the acentric factor. The product of this quantity, the fugacity coefficient, and the Poynting correction factor gives the fugacity of a pure liquid. The log of this quantity equals A minus B over quantity C minus temperature, where A, B and C are all constants, according to the (*) Antoine equation. For a pure component, this quantity equals its total times the mole fraction of that component according to Raoult’s law. This quantity is equal to atmospheric pressure at the boiling point. For 10 points, name this quantity, which is the pressure exerted by a gas over a liquid.

Critics have argued that the 24 lines in the second and fourth stanzas of this poem are a coded reference to the date of the events which inspired it. The speaker of this poem reluctantly acknowledges a “drunken vainglorious lout” who was married to the poet’s longtime crush, and asserts that “He, too, has resigned his part / in the casual comedy.” The speaker of this poem later laments that “too long a sacrifice / Can make a stone of the heart,” and prior to that, the third stanza compares a stone in the midst of a “living stream” to “Hearts with one purpose alone.” This poem repeats (*) “A terrible beauty is born,” referring to the executions of James Connolly, Patrick Pearse, and their colleagues for their actions during the title time. For 10 points, name this poem by William Butler Yeats written in response to an Irish uprising against British rule.

A book titled for this location advises “To arrive at being all desire to be nothing” in its opening poem “The Dark Night of the Soul”. A man used twelve stones to build an altar at this location before pouring twelve jars of water over the wood he used for an offering. A statue of a man raising a sword to kill a man whose head he’s stepping on is located here at the site of Al-Muhraqa. The Rule of St. Albert governs an organization named for this location whose members wear the (*) Brown Scapular. Teresa of Avila and John of the Cross helped create a Discalced order named for this location. 450 priests were slaughtered in the Kishon valley after they failed to get Ba’al to create a fire for their sacrifice at this location. The Universal House of Justice is located at, for 10 points, what mountain range where Elijah defeats Ahab’s priests to prove the superiority of God?

During this decade, an artist painted a nostalgic black and white mural titled Once Upon a Time on the walls of a community center’s public bathroom. A giant text bubble looms over an enormous crowd surfing skeleton in a red mural painted at a playground during this decade. During this decade, three yellow figures performing the “three wise monkeys” gestures with X’s on their torsos were painted above the words (*) “Silence = Death.” Many paintings featuring the “radiant baby” motif were created by Keith Haring during this decade. The NAMES Project created a massive memorial quilt during this decade as part of a campaign that also featured a pink triangle used by the activist group ACT UP. For 10 points, name this decade during which LGBT artists criticized the government’s lack of response to the AIDS crisis.

This man’s son Maurice was briefly elected Duke of Courland, a position he sought to reclaim after becoming a Marshal of France. This man turned the Green Vault in his capital into a public museum and modeled his Zwinger palace on Versailles. This monarch’s courtier Berend Lehmann financed his election to one position, in which he struggled with the Tarnogród Confederation until the coercive mediation of Peter the Great at the (*) “Silent Sejm” (“SAME”). Seeking the secret of transmuting gold, this ruler imprisoned alchemist Johann Friedrich Böttger (“BOOT-ger”), who instead developed the Meissen variety of porcelain. France fought Austria and Russia after this man’s death over the competing claims of his son and Stanisław Leszczyński (“stan-EES-lav les-chay-in-SKI”). For 10 points, name this Elector of Saxony and King of Poland known for his physical prowess.
tossups.answer: Augustus the Strong [or Augustus II; or August II Mocny; or August der Starke; or Frederick Augustus I; or Friedrich August I; prompt on Augustus; prompt on Frederick Augustus]

tossups.question: An instrument used to image this region contains a series of baffles called Lyot stops. This region’s “E” sub-region is characterized by lines generated by highly ionized iron, while its “K” sub-region is created by scattering of free electrons. A belt of helmet streamers exists in this region, and magnetic field lines can escape through this region’s namesake holes. A magnetic carpet and spicules may explain the temperature of this region, arcades in which were imaged by the TRACE and (*) SOHO missions. An ongoing mystery is why this region is millions of kelvin hotter than the surface of the body that it surrounds. A mass ejection from this region can be preceded by a powerful solar flare. For 10 points, name this layer of plasma that surrounds the sun.
tossups.answer: solar corona [prompt on stellar atmosphere or solar atmosphere or atmosphere of the sun or equivalents; prompt on sun]

tossups.question: In the preface to this play, its author claimed “the purpose of comedy is to correct men’s vices” and that “people have no objection to being considered wicked, but they are not willing to be considered ridiculous.” In this play, one character insults another by saying “f, o, o, l, / Just spells your name.” A servant woman in this play says “Good! That’s a remedy I hadn’t thought of. / Just die, and everything will be all right” when a woman says she’ll kill herself if she’s forced into marriage. That woman’s father ignores his wife’s sickness, repeating (*) “Poor man!” when told about the gluttony of a man in this play who steals a box of letters left by Argas. A man hiding under a table in this play observes that character trying to seduce Elmire. This play ends with Louis XIV arresting the title character, saving Orgon and his family from eviction. For 10 points, name this Moliere play about a religious hypocrite.

In one of these pieces in G major, the opening features a piccolo solo which begins with an ascending (read slowly) G – D – D – E in a short-short-long-long rhythm. Another piece of this type by the same composer begins with the double basses playing arpeggios on the open strings as if they are still tuning, and they are soon joined by a contrabassoon solo. A piece of this type by a different composer imitates ship propellers in its third movement while the second movement quotes a Nubian love song. A (*) whip crack opens one of these pieces in G major by Maurice Ravel, whose other piece of this type is in D major and was written for World War I veteran Paul Wittgenstein. Camille Saint-Saëns’s fifth piece of this type is subtitled “Egyptian,” and Ravel wrote one in which the soloist only plays with the left hand. For 10 points, name these pieces for a keyboard instrument and orchestra.
tossups.answer: piano concertos [or concertos for piano and orchestra; accept Maurice Ravel’s piano concertos before “ship propellers”; after “ship propellers,” prompt on Ravel’s piano concertos or Saint-Saëns’s piano concertos with “be less specific”]

tossups.question: This man described Louis XIV bullying Genoan leaders into seeking pardon in his essays “Concerning Dangers from Foreign Force and Influence.” This governor of New York signed a law declaring newborn children of slaves to be 25-year indentured servants and founded the New York Manumission Society. Congress refused to ratify a 1786 “Liberty Treaty” giving up American navigation rights on the Mississippi that this diplomat negotiated with Diego de Gardoqui. Jeffersonians entreated listeners to (*) “Damn every one that won’t damn” this man for signing a treaty which reestablished normal trade relations with Britain. This man authored early essays of The Federalist Papers alongside Alexander Hamilton and James Madison. For 10 points, name this first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

This phenomenon is the second stage in Irving Fisher's 1933 theory of the Great Depression's cause. This phenomenon generally causes government seigniorage to be less profitable. Neo-Keynesians believe this phenomenon increased companies' debt exposure during the so-called "balance sheet recession" of Japan's Lost Decade, and it also exacerbated the contemporaneous liquidity trap. Paul Krugman's Depression Economics identified a (*) spiral between debt and this phenomenon as partially responsible for slowing demand during the recession as consumers held onto liquid cash due to further expectations of this phenomenon. To combat this phenomenon, Japan and six European countries issued negative interest rates. For 10 points, name this phenomenon of generally decreasing prices, the opposite of inflation.

bonuses.leadin: This ancient algorithm can be used to find all the prime numbers up to a given limit. For 10 points each:
answers: x divided by log of x [or x over log x; accept “ln” or “logarithm” or “natural logarithm” instead of “log”]
parts: Name this algorithm that works by iteratively labeling all multiples of primes as composite and thereafter crossing them out which leaves only the prime numbers behind.

Calculating the time complexity of the Sieve of Eratosthenes relies on summing this series over the prime numbers. This series equals one plus one-half plus one-third plus one-fourth and so on, and it slowly diverges.
The prime number theorem states that, asymptotically, the prime counting function of x approximately equals this function of x.

bonuses.leadin: Note to moderator: do not read aloud any of the full answers or prompt lines. For 10 points each, name some Islamic collective terms:
answers: People of the Book [or People of the Scripture; or Ahl al-Kitab; prompt on Ahl al-Dhimmi]
Ahl al-Bayt [prompt on Family of the House with “can you give the Arabic term?”]
parts: In early Islamic history, Christians, Jews, and Sabians were known as the “people of” this thing because they adhered to monotheistic scriptures.
This overarching term refers to the Muslim community as a whole, regardless of national or ancestral background.

In Shia Islam, this term refers to relatives of Muhammad and some infallible imams, while to Sunnis it only refers to some members of Muhammad’s family. In English, it roughly translates to “People of the House.”

bonuses.leadin: This standard was introduced in Footnote Four of U.S. v. Carolene Products. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this standard of judicial review. To pass this standard, laws must be narrowly tailored to meet a compelling government interest while employing the least restrictive means.
This 1944 Supreme Court decision concerning interned Japanese-Americans during World War II was the first case to withstand strict scrutiny.
This Chief Justice authored Footnote Four and the Carolene Products opinion, and addressed jurisdiction over unlawful combatants in Ex Parte Quirin.

bonuses.leadin: This novel begins with the statement “Everything in the world begins with a yes. One molecule said yes to another molecule and life was born.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this book that ends with the death of the protagonist when she is hit by a yellow Mercedes immediately after visiting a fortune teller.
This woman hits and kills Myrtle while driving a yellow car that belongs to someone who is later shot for the accident in a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

Although it is not used to hit anyone, a yellow pickup truck is a prized possession in this novel. After the title character takes it, Maureen waits outside in the rain naked until she sees the truck return.

bonuses.leadin: Alan Hovhannes wrote a “double” example of this form as the middle movement of his “Mysterious Mountain” Symphony. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this contrapuntal form in which each voice states a subject in turn. J.S. Bach paired a spooky toccata in D minor with a piece in this form.
This Canadian pianist turned the rules of writing fugue into lyrics in his vocal piece So You Want to Write a Fugue? His career took off with a 1955 recording of Bach’s Goldberg Variations.

Gould warned that diminution combined with this technique, usually employed towards the end of a fugue, was an “obvious solution.” This Italian term refers to starting the answer in one voice before the previous voice has finished the subject, so they overlap.

bonuses.leadin: In the encyclical Praedecessores nostros, this Pope granted a seven-year indulgence to anyone who attended three days of public prayer over the Irish famine. For 10 points each:
answers: Pope Pius IX [or Giovanni Maria Mastai Ferretti]
parts: Name this Pope who restored a Roman Catholic diocesan (“DYE-oh-SEE-sin”) hierarchy to England in the 1850 bull Universalis Ecclesiae. This pope convened the First Vatican Council and promulgated the dogma of the Immaculate Conception.

Though he had introduced the repeal of the discriminatory Test Acts, this Prime Minister responded to the papal bull by banning the use of the new Catholic titles. This Whig championed the 1832 Reform Act under Lord Grey.

British public opinion also turned on this High Church movement led by John Henry Newman, whose leaders had mostly converted to Catholicism. This movement is named for its association with a university that traditionally rivals Cambridge.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about theories in developmental psychology. For 10 points each.
answers: trust [accept mistrust; accept trust versus mistrust]
John Bowlby [or Edward John Mostyn Bowlby]
parts: This Swiss psychologist proposed that children proceed through sensorimotor, preoperational, concrete operational, and formal operational stages.

Psychologist Erik Erikson envisioned developmental stages as progressing through various conflicts. In his model, the first stage of development—from ages 0 to 1.5—has a basic virtue of hope and a psychosocial crisis defined by the presence or absence of this concept.
According to this British psychologist's attachment theory, infants who experience maternal deprivation would undergo separation anxiety.

bonuses.leadin: This city is home to the O'Connell's Pub, where one character wants to hang a portrait of Mangal Pandey, and which is finally opened to women at the end of one novel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city. Karim leaves the suburbs to come here while his father hosts guru sessions in Hanif Kureishi's The Buddha of Suburbia.
Samad Iqbal immigrates from Bangladesh to London after World War II and becomes friends with Archie Jones in this author's novel White Teeth.

In this book by Monica Ali named for a Bengali district in London, Nazneen has to scrape the corns off her husband Chanu's feet, writes to her sister Hasina in Bangladesh, and has an affair with Karim.

bonuses.leadin: Children with chickenpox who are given this drug may develop Reye’s syndrome. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this anti-inflammatory drug commonly used for fever and mild aches. 81 milligrams of this drug per day is used as primary prevention against cardiovascular events.
NSAIDs like aspirin target COX-1, inhibiting the formation of these signaling molecules made from cell membrane lipids that are involved in smooth muscle contraction.
Aspirin also modifies COX-2, inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins and these compounds which bind platelets together. Their A2 variety is released by activated platelets.

bonuses.leadin: Albin Grau’s production designs for this film were inspired by Hugo Steiner-Prag’s illustrations for a story about a golem. For 10 points each:
answers: Nosferatu: A Symphony of Horror [or Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens]
parts: Name this film directed by F.W. Murnau which stars Max Schreck as Orlok, who pursues the real estate agent Thomas Hutter.
Nosferatu was an unauthorized adaptation of this novel by Bram Stoker. Bela Lugosi starred as the title character in Tod Browning’s 1931 film based on it.

Horror films and other stylized genres typically used a lighting setup with a high “ratio” of intensity for the key light relative to this other type of light. A traditional three-point setup consists of a key light, a back light, and one of these.

bonuses.leadin: This man labeled the Arab Joint List “an enemy” and refused to sit with them “even in a parallel universe.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this former Minister of Defense who leads the Yisrael Beitenu party. This man’s insistence on removing the draft exemptions for the ultra-Orthodox led to another round of Israeli elections in September 2019.
This current Prime Minister has been unable to hold Yisrael Beitenu and ultra-Orthodox parties in the same coalition, preventing him from obtaining a majority in the Knesset (“kuh-NESS-it”).

Lieberman has urged for a unity government with Netanyahu’s Likud and this alliance, which now holds the most seats in the Knesset. This party’s leader Benny Gantz has refused to partner with Likud as long as Netanyahu leads it.

bonuses.leadin: Two artists required. The pose of the title figure in one of these artist’s The Buffoon Pablo de Valladolid inspired the other artist’s painting The Tragic Actor. For 10 points each:
answers: Bacchus [or Dionysus; or The Triumph of Bacchus]
parts: Name these artists. The earlier artist’s self portrait with the red cross of the Order of Santiago inspired the later artist to paint a self-portrait over a portrait of his wife Suzanne, who shared modeling duties with Victorine Meurent.

In a letter to Henri-Fantin Latour, Manet described being dazzled by this painting, which contains that Velazquez self-portrait. This group portrait of the Spanish court centers on the Infanta Margaret Theresa.

The background of Manet’s Portrait of Emile Zola features a Goya reproduction of a Velázquez painting of this god. That rowdy group portrait shows this god’s “triumph” as he crowns a man with a wreath.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things related to quinine total synthesis. For 10 points each:
parts: This Harvard chemist was the first to achieve quinine total synthesis along with William Doering. This father of total synthesis names a set of rules for predicting the stereochemistry of pericyclic reactions with Roald Hoffmann.

It is commonly believed that Woodward incorporated this chemist’s method in synthesizing enantiopure quinotoxine for his synthesis. Along with Cahn and Ingold, this man co-names a set of rules for naming stereoisomers.

The final step of Prelog’s synthesis involved Claisen reaction, which is this type of molecular addition reaction that generates water. This type of reaction is thus the reverse of a hydrolysis reaction.

bonuses.leadin: In Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity, Richard Rorty borrows his definition of “liberal” as someone who thinks that cruelty is the worst thing a person can do from this thinker. For 10 points each:
answers: Charles-Louis de Secondat, baron de Montesquieu
parts: Identify this political philosopher, who coined the idea of the “liberalism of fear,” in an essay of the same name, and further explored the political ramifications of cruelty in the 1984 book Ordinary Vices.

Rorty invokes Shklar’s definition in the context of this writer, who wrote about cruelty “from the outside.” This writer’s non-fiction work includes essays such as “Good Bad Books” and a semi-autobiographical book that includes photographs of Welsh coal miners.

Shklar wrote a classic introduction to the thought of this philosopher, who satirised Christian society through the eyes of Uzbek and Rica in his Persian Letters and also wrote The Spirit of the Laws.

bonuses.leadin: One of this author's characters tapped out the message "I love you" in individual letters, leading a theater critic to say "If he does ‘y’, I'm through. And he did. So I shot myself." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author whose use of the word "hummy" elicited the line "Tonstant Weader Fwowed up" from a New Yorker book review.

This author savaged A. A. Milne in her "Constant Reader" book reviews. This woman known for her bon mots wrote about Hazel Morse's attempted suicide in "Big Blonde” and quipped “You might as well live” in “Resume.”
Dorothy Parker was a member of this "Vicious Circle" of New York wits also including George S. Kaufman and Robert Benchley.

bonuses.leadin: The national dress of this ethnic group includes a shashka sword and a bandolier of gunpowder worn around the coat. For 10 points each:
answers: Alexander II of Russia [prompt on Alexander]
parts: Name this ethnic group that was ethnically cleansed under the supervision of Dmitriy Milyutin. This people’s flag contains three crossed arrows of gold pointing to an arc of stars on a field of green.

This Tsar ordered the resettlement of Circassian lands with Kuban cossacks. This Tsar established the zemstvo system but died before he could implement the constitutional initiatives of Count Loris Melikov.
Many Circassians refuse to eat fish in memory of their ancestors who died during their forced crossing of this sea from the Caucasus into Anatolia.

bonuses.leadin: This figure lazily dragged a string across mud, making lower-class humans, instead of carefully molding them as she did for nobles. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Chinese creator goddess, the wife and sister of Fuxi (“FOO-shee”). This goddess also helped to repair the Pillar of Heaven by replacing the four columns holding up the sky.

Nüwa replaced those columns with the legs of one of these animals named Ao, which resides in the Bohai Sea with islands on his back. The “world” example of these animals is often depicted carrying the world, and in some myths an elephant.

In the Legend of the White Snake, this figure sells immortality pills to an unsuspecting boy named Xu Xian (“SHU SHEE-an”), but his main vocation was poetry. This figure was a real Tang Dynasty scholar but was later elevated to divine status.

bonuses.leadin: This man wrote “Do not feel safe. The poet remembers. / You can kill one, but another is born” in “You Who Wronged.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet who wrote about Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta in The Captive Mind, which attempts to explain why Stalinism appeals to intellectuals.
Miłosz hails from this Eastern European country. The author of Quo Vadis, Henryk Sinkiewicz (“shen-KYEY-vitch”), is from here.
This Irish poet, who wrote about seeing creatures “poised like mud grenades” that created “warm thick slobber” in one work, was heavily influenced by Miłosz and read a poem at his funeral.

bonuses.leadin: The rate of this process is governed by the Einstein coefficient B21 (“B-sub-two-one”). For 10 points each:
answers: helium OR neon [or He OR Ne]
parts: Name this process in which a photon interacts with an excited electron to produce another photon with the same phase and frequency. It generates most of the light output by lasers and is contrasted with spontaneous emission.

Laser scanners in supermarkets typically used a mixture of two gases as the gain medium to produce a red beam. Name either of those two gases, which were also used to create the first gas laser of any wavelength.

The first wideband tunable lasers were this type, which use dissolved organic molecules such as Rhodamine 6G as the gain medium. Though largely replaced by solid-state lasers, they are still used in spectroscopy.

bonuses.leadin: The highest-ranking Buddhist cleric in this country is the Jebtsundamba (“TCHAWT-sun-DAWM-buh”). For 10 points each:
answers: Khorloogiin Choibalsan [10 A Buddhist revival has grown in Mongolia since the 1990 revolution focused at Sükhbaatar Square in this capital, whose name literally means “Red Hero.” ANSWER: Ulaanbaatar
parts: Name this country where Baron Roman Ungern von Sternberg propped up the government of the eighth Jebtsundamba, Bogd Khan.

Once the Red Army toppled Ungern von Sternberg, this early Mongolian leader liquidated Mongolian Buddhist institutions and clergy after pushing out Peljidiin Genden, who had denied Stalin’s requests to do so.
